title: 107_hr4033
content: The Act is titled the "Living Equitably: Grandparents Aiding Children and Youth Act" and includes a demonstration program for elderly housing for intergenerational families. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a demonstration program to provide intergenerational dwelling units for families in connection with the supportive housing program. Assistance will be given to nonprofit organizations to expand the supply of these units by retrofitting existing units or developing new buildings. The program aims to provide intergenerational dwelling units through the development of buildings or projects, including elder cottage housing units, as part of the supportive housing program. Assistance will be subject to the provisions of the Housing Act of 1959. The demonstration program for intergenerational dwelling units under the Housing Act of 1959 allows for occupancy as specified, exempts certain application and selection criteria, mandates tailored services for occupants, and permits waivers of other provisions as needed. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will select 2-4 projects for assistance under section 202 of the Housing Act of 1959 based on the ability to develop intergenerational dwelling units and national geographical diversity. The term "elderly person" is defined as in section 202(k) of the Housing Act of 1959. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will choose 2-4 projects for assistance under section 202 of the Housing Act of 1959 to develop intergenerational dwelling units for elderly persons. A report on the program's effectiveness must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will reserve funds for demonstration projects under section 202 of the Housing Act of 1959 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. These funds are specifically allocated for providing assistance under this section. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will reserve funds for a demonstration program for rental assistance for grandparent-headed or relative-headed families. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a demonstration program to provide rental assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 for covered families. Public housing agencies selected for the program can use reserved rental assistance amounts for qualified dwelling units. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will require public housing agencies to provide tailored supportive services to covered families receiving rental assistance. Agencies can apply to participate in the demonstration program during fiscal years 2003 through 2006, with not less than two and not more than four agencies selected based on their ability to provide assistance and services. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will require public housing agencies to provide tailored supportive services to covered families receiving rental assistance. Agencies can apply to participate in the demonstration program during fiscal years 2003 through 2006, with not less than two and not more than four agencies selected based on their ability to provide assistance and services. The program aims to promote national geographical diversity among participating agencies. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of the Act, analyzing the program's effectiveness. Funding for voucher assistance will be reserved for selected agencies to provide assistance under this section. ELIGIBILITY OF GRANDPARENT-HEADED AND RELATIVE-HEADED FAMILIES FOR FAMILY UNIFICATION ASSISTANCE. Section 8(x) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include eligibility for family assistance for rental of a qualified dwelling unit for covered families as defined in the Living Equitably: Grandparents Aiding Children and Youth Act. Section 8(x) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to include eligibility for family assistance for rental of a qualified dwelling unit for covered families as defined in the Living Equitably: Grandparents Aiding Children and Youth Act, with additional provisions for describing the need for assistance under this subsection. SEC. 5 amends the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act to include cottage housing units for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families. SEC. 6 provides assistance for education and outreach on housing opportunities for these families under the Fair Housing Initiatives Program. Section 561 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to include education, outreach, counseling, and assistance programs for informing covered families of affordable housing opportunities. Additionally, housing programs for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families are added. The Secretary will provide funding for housing programs for grandparent-headed and relative-headed families through State and local governments, as well as public and nonprofit organizations. Training for HUD personnel on issues related to grandparent-headed and relative-headed families will be provided. The Department of Housing and Urban Development Act is amended to require training for HUD personnel on issues related to grandparent-headed and relative-headed families, ensuring they understand the specific needs and problems of these families, including affordable housing opportunities and legal custody issues. SEC. 8. STUDY OF HOUSING NEEDS OF GRANDPARENT-HEADED AND RELATIVE-HEADED FAMILIES. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and the Bureau of the Census will conduct a study to estimate the number of covered families in the US and their affordable housing needs. A report with recommendations on utilizing major housing programs must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of this Act's enactment. The Housing Act of 1959 can be amended to meet the affordable housing needs of covered families. The Housing Act of 1959 can be amended to meet the affordable housing needs of covered families by defining key terms. The Housing Act of 1959 can be amended to meet the affordable housing needs of covered families by defining key terms related to children, covered families, and grandparents. The term "qualified dwelling unit" refers to a dwelling unit with at least 2 separate bedrooms and design features for elderly and young children. "Raising a child" means residing with and being the primary caregiver for the child. The term "relative" refers to an individual who is not a parent of the child by blood or marriage, but is a blood relative of the child. The individual serves as the primary caregiver for the child regardless of any legal relationship or guardianship. The term "relative" includes individuals who are blood or marriage relatives of the child, regardless of the child's age or adoption status.
